Description: Plaque, rectangular; painted Limoges enamel on copper: St Anthony Abbot and St Paul the Hermit. Saint Anthony identified by the Tau cross on his robes. Both seated in a rocky landscape outside of a cave, reaching to accept a loaf of bread from mouth of dove descending from Heaven. On the lower right within a laurel wreath, the coat of arms of Jean de Langeac, Bishop of Limoges. Signed and dated on the front. Painted with semi-opaque, and over foil with translucent enamels in brown, green and ruby; details gilt. Counter-enamel translucent and colourless.
Curator's comments: Part of a set with 1913, 12-20, 28. On Langeac, see Bodin, "Jean de Langeac, mecene et humaniste", Bulletin de la societe archaeologique et historique du Limousin, LXXXVI, 1955, p.81-104.
Bibliographic references: Baratte, 1993 / Léonard Limosin au musée du Louvre (p.40 pl. 16)
La Niece et al 2009 / Limoges painted enamels: evidence for specialist copper-smithing workshops (p.13)
Associated names: Representation of: St Antony of Egypt
Representation of: St Paul the Hermit
Emblem of: Jean de Langeac, Bishop of Limoges
